sentences_tone.text: FANG Is Dead - Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROToday's MarketEconomyGold & Precious MetalsCommoditiesForexReal EstateEditor's PicksFANG Is DeadNov.11.16 | About: Amazon.com,

Inc. (AMZN) Andrew McElroy Follow Long/short equity, long-term horizon, medium-term horizon, short-term horizonSend MessageSummaryFANG stocks have led the market for the last two years.Amazon is the leader of FANG stocks.What happens when the leader of the leaders rolls over?Amazon's (NASDAQ:AMZN) importance to the stock market can't be overstated.
Every equity rally has its leader, and through 2015-2016, Amazon has been the stock forging ahead to new all-time highs and setting the pace.

Among the so-called "FANG" stocks (Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Amazon, Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) and Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) (NASDAQ:GOOGL)), only Netflix comes close in terms of performance, and it does so with a $52bn market cap compared to Amazon's $358bn.
Click to enlarge Source: Google Finance And it's not just the percentage gains.
Amazon's lead in the cloud space was a big catalyst for tech in the last two years.
Google and Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) were playing catch up, both in the cloud, but also in the position of their rallies.
This is something I've written about a number of times and have provided a few decent trades.
When Google (and Microsoft) gapped to new highs in 2016, it was something we had seen with Amazon about three months earlier.
When they re-tested the break-out, I used previous the Amazon price action to predict the level would hold and lead to a rally in Google.

This was from my article in early September:
Google and Microsoft soon followed Amazon higher.
So Amazon leads FANG stocks, which lead (and often hold up) the market.
When Amazon (the general) is shot, the troops are in disarray.
Amazon's earnings miss on the 27th October led to a heavy sell-off the next day.
Google soon followed despite posting a beat of top- and bottom-line earnings estimates and making a brief all-time high of $839.
The sell-off in Amazon obviously spooked investors and Google quickly declined 8%, making a three-month low only five days later.
In fact, I was one of those investors.
As I said in my September article: If Google continues to try and catch up with Amazon, it should end its consolidation very soon and continue higher to above $820 by November.
What happens after that is up to Amazon's lead.
I had already closed half of my long position at my $825 target, but wanted to hold the rest for higher.
When I saw what Amazon did after earnings, I changed my plans pretty quickly.
How Bad Is The Amazon Sell-Off?
Amazon has had sharp sell-offs before and every time it has recovered and made another all-time high.
Long-term holders have seen it all before, and I'm sure they won't be in a panic.
That doesn't mean Amazon will keep going up and up forever.
The equity bull market in the S&P 500 (NYSEARCA:SPY) is the second longest ever.
You cannot argue with the fact Amazon and the market are mature and will pull back at some point.
I've been approaching the market with a fairly short-term tactic and will not buy and hold anything at this stage in the bull run, no matter how good a company it is.

My July 22nd article, "Why I Bought Amazon At $690 - And Will Be Out At $800" received a mixed response, especially from long-term holders: Your article was a grand waste of your time and mine - see you at $1,000+ This kind of complacency is dangerous.
Bears are always mocked at market tops (see the quote from Wikipedia below).
And for the record, my article was not a waste of time for anyone trading Amazon in the last six months.
Yesterday's low was 10% below my exit price.
My reasons for selling were down to my interpretation of Elliott Wave cycles.
I personally don't know if the recent Amazon miss is hugely significant or how to value a company so large.
I rely on other people knowing this, and I look at how they are behaving.
On the long-term weekly chart, Amazon has been in a wave 5 rally from the February lows.
This is what Wikipedia says about a wave 5: Wave 5: Wave five is the final leg in the direction of the dominant trend.
The news is almost universally positive and everyone is bullish.
Unfortunately, this is when many average investors finally buy in, right before the top.
Volume is often lower in wave five than in wave three, and many momentum indicators start to show divergences (prices reach a new high but the indicators do not reach a new peak).
At the end of a major bull market, bears may very well be ridiculed (recall how forecasts for a top in the stock market during 2000 were received).

And here is the chart:
Click to enlarge This is just an updated chart from my September article.
Note the momentum divergence and drop-off in volume as described in the Wikipedia passage above.
The S&P 500 is in a similar part of its cycle, but I suspect it may rumble along for a while yet.
To conclude, it looks like there is a complete, long-term cycle present in Amazon, and there is a medium-term top present.
This will be corrected by time and price and should eventually break the channel shown in the next few years.
In the very long term, Amazon will likely continue higher.
Shorter Term There is a nice pattern forming in the shorter term.
Amazon should complete its first leg down around the 2015 high and the 200 dma at $697.
The bounce from here could take it right back toward $800 again.

Click to enlarge
I'm watching the sell-off closely as it already looks quite similar to December '15 to February '16.
The initial drop from $697 on 30th December '15 to $547 on 20th January was $150.
If Amazon was to do something similar now, a $150 drop takes it from the $847 to exactly $697, the support we already identified.
A comparative bounce would take it $93 higher, but let's see if $697 area holds first.
FANG Stocks Without their general, FANG stocks will struggle.

Facebook (on a log chart) looks like it may have completed the trend sequence with the completion of a wedge for wave 5.
Click to enlarge Google looks like it may have completed 5 waves, and is at the top of its channel.
Click to enlarge Netflix (on a log chart) is at the top of its channel, but the count isn't too clear.
Click to enlarge I can't say I am 100% certain the top for FANG is in, but I wouldn't initiate a new buy-and-hold position here.
Conclusions There appears to be a major shift underway in the markets.
Amazon may have topped, and FANG stocks are finally correcting.
This doesn't necessarily mean the market will top straight away.
The shift into oversold sectors since Trump's victory shows how markets can rise without FANG stocks.
However, longer term, this may be the beginning of the end.
I will continue to look for longs with a shorter-term perspective and adapt my methods to the market as I see it.
Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, but may initiate a long position in AMZN over the next 72 hours.
